Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: To locate a [choker](https://www.google.com/) not located in a [jewelry box](https://www.journaltimes.com/news/national-international/what-s-in-a-jewelry-box-and-why-is-it-important/collection_1c929e19-5c60-5636-9e4b-2249d55d427d.html) or [boutique](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/boutique), where would you go?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In the previous instruction, the "choker" was not located in the jewelry box. Hence, we will want to go to a jewelry store to find the choker.<n><n>### Output:<n>The choker is not located in the j[e](https://www.grammarbook.com/punctuation/comma_and_semicolon.asp)wlery box or boutique. Choice: A: jewlery store<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are several choices here. I would put my grapes right before checking out in my fruit basket, because I could take it home with me instead of the fruit market.<n><n>### Input :Why did he go out of town last week? Choices: 	A: to meet friends and family 		B: for new experiences 		C: to enjoy sight-seeing 			D: to sight-see 			E: for vacation <n><n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. A- It doesn't make much sense to go out of town to meet family and friends. Going out of town would usually mean visiting people who aren't part of the household such as family at a far-off farm or a significant other's family.<n>2. B- Going out of town for new experiences usually goes together with sight-seeing.<n>3. C- Sight-seeing can be either a verb or a noun. It makes no sense to'sight-see' the town. This choice is incorrect here.<n>4. D- It makes perfect sense to sight-see when going out of town. This works as an adequate answer<n>5. E- It makes sense to go out of for vacation as if someone is going to stay at a beach front resort.<n>6. In conclusion, we conclude that the right choice is the one that has a lot of meaning and sense to it and if the person will most likely carry out the action given. This makes the most sense out of all, choice D.<n>Answer: D: to sight-see

Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>The words living room and kitchen are incorrect as they both describe the room itself, not the aromas. <n><n>The words basement and garden are also incorrect as they both refer to the physical space and not the aromas that come from within that space. <n><n>The word 'yard' doesn't make much of a difference in this sentence so it can be excluded as well. <n><n>The answer is therefore B: basement. <n>

Choices:  A: chicago B: street C: little italy D: food court E: capital cities<n><n>### Response:		<n>Where I would most likely expect to find a pizza parlor is in the food court. <n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. Capital cities and street are not good choices because the capital city of any state and the streets in large cities are probably not where you would find a pizza parol;<n>2. The food court is made up of a bunch of small restaurants, shops, and vendors who sell different food items from each other, including pizza,<n>5. There are many people in the food court, so finding a pizza parlor here is not as difficult.

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		<n>After analyzing all of the provided choices, choice B:'radio' describes the connection of files by best matching the description. The phrase "you can share files with someone" suggests that there is some type of electronic link or connection between two parties for the exchange of information. Choice A: 'freeway' is not applicable because a freeway is an actual road and not electronic. Choice C: 'wires' does not relate to files being shared as 'wires' are cords used to move information from one device to another. Choice D: Computer network and Choice E: 'electrical circuit' are not applicable because neither of these options describes a connection used for sharing electronic files.<n><n>### Answer: Choice D: Computer Network<n><n>### Input:'Tesla' refers to an inventor who built the what? Choices: A: car B: telephone C: machine gun D: power grid E: lightbulb<n><n>### Response<n>We are looking for a word for what Tesla built, based on the description. Tesla was famous for his invention-related patents, and he was an electrical engineer famous for "converting AC current to DC". He also had a car company. Choice C, "machine gun" does not fit as machine guns use gunpowder to cause destruction, whereas Tesla built devices to create power. Choice D, "grid" does not fit as Tesla was an inventor who built "the light bulb." Choice E, "light bulb" is a possibility, but there is no evidence in the sentence that a lightbulb is what is being referred to.<n><n>### Anwer: D: Power grid<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: Choices B: ripped, Choices D: crumpled, Choices E: crumple it.<n>Rationales: After analyzing the choices in order from A-E, the choices that fit the description are Choices B: Ripped. This is because if you leave paper outside, it may easily become ripped because of the wind. Choices C: Saturated with water, D: Crumpled, and E: crumple It, does not fit the description. A: One material that often recycled, does not fit the sentence because recycled materials are usually collected and then shredded and reformed. C: Saturated With water, does not describe what paper could do outside, if it is saturated with water it becomes wet. D:Crumpled and E:Crumple it, do not suit the description because if paper is wet, it can also get crumpled. <n><n>Answer: B: ripped.<n><n>### Input The sentence "the computer is the fastest device.<n>### Asked: What are some words that do not mean the same as the word device?<n>### Instructions:An answer is a complete sentence.<n><n>### The word "the" does not fit in the sentence, so we should replace it with a singular pronoun.<n>### Example: It.<n>### Example 2: It is.<n>### Example<n>The word it can replace the word a device, it is, or The computer is.<n>The pronoun "it" refers to a singular noun or noun phrase. <n><n>### The pronoun 'it is' refers to the sentence.<n><n>The word 'it' can refer to the sentence, in which case, we would write "it is".<n><n>### Answer: 'it' is or it is. <n><n>##  Input:"Jimmy was so thirsty, he could be drinking water now." <n>## <n><n>### Input:"Either, you help or I am going to quit my job" <n>### Instruments:<n>### Input:"I am either going to study for my exams or work this evening"<n>### Instrucement:<n>The word "or", can be replaced with an alternation or an alternative: "and then" or

Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		 <n>The given phrase suggests that driving should be "safe". The choices are not all safe, hence, we know that the answer should not be any of the choices given.<n>We now proceed to find if driving safely is fun, dangerous, illegal, or deadly.<n>1. Choice A:'stressful' is not safe as stress is dangerous and therefore not a safe choice.<n>2. Choice B:  'dangerous' is not a safe word in this context as it contradicts the "safe" theme.<n>3. Choice C: 'fun' would be safe if driving can be fun, and hence, is an appropriate choice.<n>4. Choices D E & F describe negative traits of driving, hence, not safe and cannot be the correct answer.<n>5. Therefore, according to all observations, the correct answer is C: 'fun because it is the word that best corresponds to what the writer is describing.<n><n>```

The ball has a flat, smooth surface, it is round and bounces and has a lot of air inside. Choices: A. a ball B. a sphere C. a spherical figure D. a circle<n>Rationales: the given question asks for the ball's qualities. To answer the question, we must think about what the ball has. It has a "smooth surface", a "round bounce", and "a lot of air inside". The object we are looking for is a shape, meaning the options are between A) a ball and B) a sphere. Although both have a round bounce, only a sphere is actually a spherical figure and we are looking for the closest shape to the ball. Both A& B are not related, meaning neither is the right answer. Option C) a circle can be either flat or smooth. This indicates that a circle is not a flat surface, unlike the ball. Option D) a circle is a shape, meaning it could be either flat or smooth, neither of which are in the ball's properties. Only the B, sphere answer is right.<n><n>Answer: Option B. a sphere<n><n>### Instiction:Answer the following multiple question <n>Input: What does a ball do? Instead, getting paid brings us a sense of fulfilment, satisfaction or accomplishment for having worked hard for a set period and being able to earn, which choice B exemplifies.<n><n>### Input-Choice:Getting paid feels __ing. Choices: A. income tax B. satisfaction C. sorrow D. ocean E. bill collectors F. taxi driver G. to happy H. to health<n><n>### Answer:G. Bees do not congregate with things like the trash and other forms of human waste. Therefore, the answer is most clearly choice D.<n><n>### Detailed responses: <n><n>I think that my answer was right for this question. Although I felt that I may be incorrect, I chose answer D.<n><n>## Additional Information<n>The above solution meets the following learning objectives for the assignment for this week:<n><n>* Given a multiple choice question, determine the most logical answer from a range of answers.<n>* Read and respond to a question that contains one or more phrases.<n>* Determine the meaning of a word in context.<n><n>In addition, my solution meets the following ESL specific learning objectives for this assignment:<n><n>* Read and respond with appropriate responses to questions that include phrases.<n>* Demonstrate the ability to write questions that are targeting appropriate skills to test understanding.<n>* Demonstrae the ability to write a task that is appropriate for learning of grammar points and is appropriate for specific test objectives.<n><n>### Evaluation<n><n>Please select the appropriate rubric below to evaluate the solution.<n><n>## Rubric<n>### ESL - Read and Respond with appropriate answers<n><n>* [ESL – Read and Respond with an appropriate answer to a question that contains phrases](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1k0nNrXvx8R1qnvFHgC5s1Kb3DlHbXR6n8xK5uqzVtKDs/edit?usp=sharing)<n><n>_ESL  – Read an question that contains phrases and select an appropriate answer_<n><n>_Note_<n><n>* The ESL rubric has been created by the [IELTS Writing Team](https://github.com/IELTS1), based on [the feedback](https://github.github.com/IEETS1/IEETS1.Sandbox.v1/issues/141) of IELTS teacher.<n>* This rubric should not be used to assess students' writing performances in IELTS exam.<n>* This rubic should be used strictly for
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:The city's community garden was demolished for yet another what? Choices:  A: wasteland B: ocean C: desert D: parking lot E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>The given phrase says that the city's community garden is being demolished for yet another parking lot. <n><n>### Demisturation:<n>1. The given phrase, "[Yet another parking lot..]" provides the reader with context about the demolition of the community garden.<n>2. The choice A: "wasteland" does not suit this statement because a wasteland is usually a barren and abandoned area. However, a parking lot would be an area that is well manicured.<n>3. The given choices "ocean", "desert", "flowers" do not align with the context of the sentence as they do not describe a man-made environment.<n>4. The choice C: "ocean" does not align with the context as the community garden is located in a city.<n>5. Further analysis reveals that choice D: "parking lot" is the option that best represents the given phrase. <n>6. In conclusion, after further analysis, choice D: "park" is the correct answer as the phrase "[yet another parking lot]" is a common descriptive phrase and can be understood.<n>

Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is the letter D: "body" because, the word 'body' implies the word'skin' which best describes were the skin was cut.<n><n>### A machine was intricate, it was a:<n><n>### A. wash dishes B. apparatus C. box <n><n>### Demostration: <n>The phrase is "A machine was intricate". The noun is "machine" which is the subject of the sentence. "intricate" is an adjective to describe the noun "machine" which is why it is being applied to a noun to make up a combination. The subject is the noun. The answer to the question is B. <n><n>### Correct:<n>The correct answer to the question of what is referred to by the adverbial phrase "A machine was intricately..." is B. "apparatus".<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: depressed B: downcast C: angry D: unhappy E: sorrowful<n><n>### Response:		A "sad" person is not likely to be happy about being that way, so a "sad" person has a sadness, a downcast, or sorrowful mood. "Glad" and "angry" do not seem to fit well. "Unhappy" refers to how one feels about the circumstances (circumstantially unhappy). The choice B: 'downcast' and C: 'angry' both seem to be the least appropriate.<n><n>Response:B: downcast (appropriate, not happy, sad)<n>### Input: How many men does it take to open a bottle of champagne? Hardy means having strength and withstand adversity. Choices:  A: united states B: sky C: court D: field of flowers E: orchard<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. The given phrase refers to pollen that bees collect, and the question asks, "Where would you find a "bee"?<n>2. We are being asked to select a choice that corresponds to an area where this particular bee is likely to be found.<n>3. The choices A: United States, B: Sky and C: court are not related to the description of a place where bees are likely to gather pollen. In addition, the choices D: field of flowers and E: orchard are also not applicable.<n>4. Hence, the only option that makes sense is choice B: sky because a sky has no relation to an area where pollination can take place.<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input:"In this case, you are dealing with a non-linear system." Which is true about linear systems? Choices: 1: they are complex 2: they are continuous 3: they are discontinuous Choice 4: they are difficult to solve<n><n>### Response:"In this case, the phrase that precedes "in this case" is a statement that the system in the question is non-linear, and non-linear refers to a complicated or difficult system, as opposed to a system that is "Linear". <n>4. In the choices A: Non-linear systems consist of two interrelated states that are linked, such as in a non-linear system, there may be several independent inputs and outputs.<n>5. Choice B: Non-linear systems do not produce a continuous output, such as the output will appear randomly and irregularly.<n>6. The Choice C: In a non-linear system there may be several independent state variables, and these variables interact with one another to produce an outcome.<n>7. Choices D "linear systems" are simple to solve, such as when there are no disturbances.<n>8. The answer for this problem is the only one that satisfies the description, and hence the correct answer is Choice: 3<n><n>### Answer:4

The ticket booth mentioned in the sentence can be found at the _________. Choice A: train station can be found in transportation hubs rather than entertainment facilities.<n>2. The booth is not likely to be found in a cathedral or other religious center (Choice B: cathedral).<n>3. Similarly, the booth is not where people get their tickets for the underground transportation network (Choice C: metro station)<n>4. Choice D: fairgrounds refers to a theme park or entertainment park, where visitors may purchase amusement park tickets.<n>5. In the context of the statement, an amusement park is the place where tickets can be purchased.<n>6. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:After his mother saw his report card he knew he was going to be doing housework, what could have prevented this? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Demystification:The sentence states "an embarrassing situation".<n>1. "The situation" in this sentence refers to an event or circumstance that causes discomfort, shame or self-consciousness.<n>2. "To tell it people about" means to refer to a situation or event by describing it to other people.<n>3. Therefore, the verb phrase "will telling many" means "will be telling many" and "lead to" means "will lead to".<n>4. Choice A: 'notoriety' is not a logical answer because notoriety connotes widespread fame.<n>5. Choice B: "emotional distress" is not an accurate answer, in the present tense, because distress refers to an unpleasant state of mind.<n>6. Choise C: 'riot' is not logical because referring to many people to a riot is unlikely.<n>7. Choose D: "bad dreams" does not match the description of "an embarrassing what" as it cannot explain why telling everyone about embarrassing events makes them "annoyed".<n>8. In conclusion after analyzing all the choices, choice E: "annoyance" is the best answer because the verbal phrase "lead to" in the phrase "will telling many people about an " embarrassing situation" does it refer to an unpleasant result of a potentially humiliating event.<n>9. Also "lead to" when used in this sentence, has a negative connotation, indicating that telling or referring to a specific event, will result in being annoyed.<n>Answer: E: annoyance.<n>

Choices:  A: communication B: suffering C: pain D: laughter E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: The emotion people expressing themselves show is pain and suffering when they trip in front a crowd and break their legs. In line 7, the writer is talking about the trials, tribulations, and misery of someone whose leg is broken.<n><n>In the context, the given emotion is 'pain' and therefore the choice, A: 'communication' is a wrong answer choice, as the emotion is not related to communication, but rather, is related to the broken leg.<n><n>Similarly, the given emotion has to do with pain, suffering and misery and so the choice, B:'suffering' is also a wrong answer as suffering is not an emotion that people express when they trip in front and break their leg.<n><n>The choice D: 'laughter' is also a wrong choice as it does not express the right emotion; the given emotion is not laughter, but rather, suffering.<n><n>The choice, E: 'embarrassment' is also a wrong word choice as embarrassment is a different emotion than the one mentioned in the given phrase and, like the word, D: 'laughs', it does not capture the correct meaning.<n><n>The emotion that the given phrase describes is pain and suffering. Therefore, the only option that expresses the correct emotion are the choices, A: 'pain' and B:'suffer'.<n><n>Answer: A: pain, B: suffering<n><n><n>### Input : If a dog eats a piece of toast and chocolate cake, what does it become? Choices: 1.a person 2. a baby 3. a pigeon 4. a chicken 5. a monkey <n><n>### Response :<n>The term "eats" in the sentence above does not necessarily mean that the "toast" and "cake" get digested by the dog. In addition, the writer tells us that the "dog becomes" something after he ate the "toast"(line7) and "cake". Because "becomes" does not necessarily mean "digests", the choice A: 'a person' cannot be the correct answer since one cannot become a person, either digested or otherwise.<n><n>Regardless of whether the dog "digests" the toast or the cake, it becomes something else

I am choosing choice C: singing because that is the most correct answer of all of the choices.<n><n>### Further Explanation:<n><n>1. The first and third sentences of the paragraph are used to describe "a what" without telling us what the "what" is. The sentences are written as follows;<n>"A balalaika is a stringed instrument used in Russian folk music. It's also called a Russian balalaika. This instrument has three strings that are plucked by the musician from one end, which gives it a unique sound, or note. The strings are usually made of fine gut and the body is made from wood."<n><n>2. There is an underlined phrase that needs to be correctly answered, which is: "What could a balalaikas be needed for?"<n><n>3. We are given eight multiple choice choices to respond: A: artist junk yard; B: music store; C: singing; D: symphony; E: orchestra; F: choir; G: opera<n><n>4. The next step is to examine all of the choices and decide on the one that makes the most logical sense.<n><n>5. The most logical choice is option C: Singing because we are not told to provide specific information about where a balalaika can be purchased. We do not need to buy the instrument, therefore none of the other choices are applicable.<n><n>### Next Step: <n><n>1. I would like to get more practice with this task.<n><n>I chose answer C: Singing because option C was the most logical answer.

"The king" refers to a central figure, therefore, the location of the proposed meeting should not be referring to where the king is but another place where they will be meeting.<n>3. We can eliminate B: dinning room choice because it is a location where a person would meet and not a place for the meeting itself.<n>4. Choices C: throne room and D: monarchy, do not reference a location for a meeting or arrangement.<n>5. E: castle is a possible location for a meeting if the king is a monarch in charge of a castle.<n>6. The correct answer is B: court, which is the traditional space that royalty or monarchs meet for official proceedings.<n><n>### Input : The young lady was very much devoted to her studies so she received the degree.  Choices: A: honors B: academic excellence C: doctorate D: specialization E: distinction<n><n>### Response<n><n>Rationales: We are looking for a phrase that corresponds to the above description."The young lady" and "academic studies" are the two essential concepts of the question. The other choices are specific distinctions or qualifications a person might have earned in school. Choice A: 'honors' does not mean the same thing as the statement. Choices B: 'academic excellence' and D: 'distinction' refer to specific achievements of a student.  Choice E:'specialization' refers to an academic concentration, but "the young lady was very much determined to receive a university degree". In conclusion, the only choice that matches is Choice C: a 'doctorate' degree.<n><n>### Example:<n>1. If you look carefully through the text, the noun "machine" is given above.<n>2. The given description of the task implies to find a word that describes "the machine" in Choice question.<n>3. The given instructions should be followed accordingly.<n>4. The question should be answered after you have done the task described.<n><n>### Sample Input : The meeting was conducted without any confusion because the participants were familiar with the discussion. <n>Choices: A: Discreet

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where does a person need to get when they have more kids? We are then asked, "Where does a person need?" and all of the choices will be given in response. <n><n>The following template will include the following parts: <n>#### Situation description<n>* Background on the situation<n>* Details that can be found in the given situation<n>#### Question/Prompt<n>* Choices that the reader can consider (excluding answers)<n>* Questions that should be answered<n>#### Answer <n>* Proper response for the given choice (excluding response)<n>* Reason for the chosen answer

Choices D: hurt' is excluded as it would not be probable if someone got hurt solely from finding themselves after biking through rough terrain.<n>7. Choices:  A.use B.to C.of D.a E.the<n><n>### Demo:<n>We are looking for the answer choice that would properly complete the sentence. The answer choices given are:<n><n>- [A]: use<n>- [B]: to<n>- [C]: of<n>- [D]: a<n>- [E]: the<n><n>The correct answer is [D]: a, because the sentence suggests that 'a' is the thing that can be used, but does not point to the thing that can be manipulated. To manipulate something, you must use something. The sentence implies this, but does not say it directly. Choice B: to would not answer complete the sentence correctly because 'to' would not have any context. Choice C: of would not be right because of the context. Choice E: the would not answer correctly because the sentence would require the phrase a 'of the' instead of just the 'the', which would be understood. <n><n>Input:This book might be worth a second look because it is about a king who turned into a ghost. The answer D is incorrect because the phrase "Another AI machine function is *answering questions*" and the answer E is incorrect because it is a sentence fragment, not a grammatically complete answer.<n>7. In conclusion, after ruling out the choice A, B, and C, we find that the most suitable answer is D, which is "AI machines are known *for milking cows*."

Then the sentence can be divided into 4 ways. Choice A: should go by bus is wrong. Choice B: go by bus is wrong too.<n>2. The subject of the phrase is  "we" so it should be followed by verb "should" at second person. Choice C: we should go by bus is also wrong.<n>3. The subject of the sentence is "he" and it means that the sentence is at third person. The correct way to answer is use the verb at third person verb, you should "go by taxi".<n>4. An interrogative sentence will always begin with "I can go by bus or by taxicab" or "You can go by bus or taxicab" but in the sentence "Is he going by bus of by taxi?", there is no subject.<n><n>### Riddles<n><n>A carpenter made a what for Tom?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>1. Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>1. The given phrase indicates that the person was on a bus and the other passengers were quite loud, which is why he put on his headphone to relax.<n>2. We are searching for a complementary phrase that indicates that in order for him to relax, he put on his headset<n>3. The choice D: 'He put on his headphons to relax' is not correct choice <n>as he is still the active voice in the sentence. The passive voice indicates that a subject is acted upon by the verb.<n>4. The choice C: "listen to music", does not indicate that he put on his headsets in order to relax. It is just a vague response that makes the person sound like they like music.<n>5. The Choice D: " stop worrying" does not align with the description. Worrying is internal, and does not involve a physical action such as putting on headphones.<n>6. <n>7. The remaining two choices, A and B, both use the passive voice, and are therefore correct <n>as the bus in this scenario is an object being acted upon the subject.<n><n>Answer: C: headphones<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Input:He was very polite on the bus, so she gave him her seat. Choices:  A: undestroyable B: unbreakable C: indestructible D: durable E: invisible<n><n>### Response:		A person who is 'indestructible' is someone who is immune to and cannot be destroyed or damaged. In a situation where a fragile man is seeking to cause accidents, the opposite person he wants to find is someone who is indestructible, as this person would be able to withstand the accidents he causes. It is not reasonable for him to seek out someone who is 'durable' or 'undestroyable', as this does not fit the requirements of the situation. Additionally, the choice E: 'invisible' cannot work in this case as invisible people do not usually cause accidents by their mere presence. Thus, the choice A: 'indestructible', is the most matching option as 'the opposite of him' cannot refer to someone who can be harmed.<n><n>### Input- The dog is barking and a squirrel is in a tree that is?<n><n>### Response- The squirrel is in the tree that is over the dog.<n>### Input- If they were 24 hours behind the people 5 10 miles away would have seen them?<n>### Response- I am unsure about this question. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where would a ticket help you to get to a different country? Choices:  A: train station B: baseball stadium C: lottery D: movie E: bus<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice A: B: baseball stadium does not fulfill the request to be the place where a ticket helps to get to a different county; it is not a ticketed event.<n><n>Choice B: If one goes to the place B: Baseball stadium in order to use a ticket to travel, a ticket to travel will be required.<n><n>Otherwise, in order to get there one would have to have a ticket for the baseball game.<n><n>Choice C: The ticket is the same regardless of the country you are traveling from and to.<n><n>As long as the ticket is needed in-order to use the vehicle or method to travel.<n><n>Choice D: The ticket is used to travel, no matter the destination.<n><n>Choice E: If one purchases a ticket, the ticket will be required to use the vehicle or resource.<n>The ticket helps one to travel from one place to another.<n><n>To get to another place, a ticket is needed.<n><n>Choice: A The choice B: baseball stadium is the correct choice.<n><n><n>

Choices: 1 A: the semester was completed 2 B: the semeseter began 3 C: the student earned straight A's 4 D: the students learned a lot 5 E: the semester ended.<n><n>### Answer:1: A: The semester completed <n><n>### Instructin:There seems to be three little mistakes made by the sender: 1. He should of said "How are you doing?", rather then "How are you", as "how are you" is ambiguous. 2. He shouldn't of said "I forgot my phone" as he should of said "I forgot that I forgot" as "I forgot my phone", says he forgot his phone, not forgot that he forgot his phone. 3. He should of said that he was leaving his phone at the desk not "that leave my phone on the desk". <n><n>### Answer::<n>1. Dear friend, how are you doing today? I forgot my phone on the desK today. Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:A common saying, Sam thought, was to go forth, also this. Choices:  A: reverse B: backwards C: back and D: back and E: tally back<n><n>### Response:		The choices B:'reverse' and C: 'back and forth' are incorrect because they don't align with the given sentence, where the term 'also' is part of the word 'forth'. Choices D: 'back and forth', is incorrect because the correct adverb for 'forth' is actually 'back'.<n>The phrase 'also this' is an adverb phrase, so we should use a word that matches the adverb in the sentence.<n><n>Choice A:'reverse' doesn't match the sentence. Choice B: reverse' and C: 'forward' are too similar to allow us to distinguish a clear difference between the word "revers" and "back". The word "forward" is not what is called for.<n><n>Choice D: 'back and' doesn't work because the adverb phrase indicates 'and forth' so the adverb of the combined phrase would have to be "back also forth".<n><n>Choice E: 'tally' and 'back' don't work together as adjectives or adverbs. The first part of the combined sentence would be 'tally back', which doesn't make sense as an adverb. The second word 'back' is also incorrect because it is not a noun, pronoun, adjectives, adjective phrase or adverb to end with.<n><n>Thus, the correct choice is option A: (backward). As we see, the given adverb phrase is a noun phrase, and the correct adverb for that noun phrase is 'backward' the answer can not end in the adverb 'back', since that would be a preposition not an adverb.<n><n>### Input The most important question was to be about our future. Choices:  To be A: of B: in C: to D: in E: within<n>Output:To be<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the blank in each sentence with the correct word that fits the context.<n>### Rationales:<n>1. The context of the question is in regards to the phrase 'to be about'. The context of this phrase is 'to be about to' which is in regards to the term 'to be' as in the verb 'to be'. <n><n>2. The given phrase 'the most question was about our ___' is an adjective phrase, with the only question that can fit this phrase is

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Why might a person go to get counseling? Choices:  A: to be heard B: receive gifts C: understand themselves D: good things in life E: acknowledgment<n><n>### Response:		<n>The task asks why a person "might go to get counsel", which implies that there is a possibility of getting counseling. <n>### Demonstraion:<n>First, we should take a look at the choices. <n>- Choice A: 'to be heard' is not equivalent to "get counseling" because the sentence requires an action rather than a result.<n>  - Choice A does not offer an action. It offers a result, and that is clearly not what is required in the sentence.<n>- Choice B:'receive gifts' does not apply for two reasons. <n>  - First, we must not mistake the use of the word 'gifts' to mean 'good things'. Gifts refers to presents or offerings given to someone.<n>- Choice C: 'understand themselves' is not the right answer as "counseling" is not the same as "understanding oneself in a counseling setting".<n>- Choice D: 'good things in life' is not the right choice because "counseling in itself offers no good things". In order to answer this question, we will need to focus on the word 'counseling' in order to come up with the right choice.<n>- Choice E: 'acknowledgment' does not fit because a person only seeks counseling after they notice a problem.<n>  - We must take notice that the word 'counselling" is not mentioned in the sentence and must assume that the word was not omitted by accident.<n>- Finally, choice C: 'to see a counseller' is the best choice because it is the only choice that involves an action rather than the result of the action.<n>  - Choose C provides an "action" whereas the other choices only provide results, which goes against the rules of this task.<n><n>### Answer:C: to see a counseller<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: Eat<n><n>### Rationales<n>1. We can infer that there were no available food choices within the cupboard.<n>2. This indicates the people wanted to eat at home.<n>3. This response answers the question about what do the people had to do.<n>4. From the information in the prompt, we know that the cupboards had no food, so the only option is to go back to the cupboard.<n>5. Choice A: 'Cook dinner' isn’t the appropriate response because ‘cook dinner’ usually refers to the preparation of food.<n>6. Choices C and D are incorrect because they are synonyms of the given word.<n>7. Choices A, B, and C can be used interchangeably and do not provide specificity in the answer; choose only one.<n>8. Choice E is acceptable because it directly addresses the question by answering the question: How did they have to go about getting food?<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>B: eat<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The machine was very intricateso the machine must be complicated; is the answer "apparatus"?<n>2. The cupboards were barren.therefor, the cupboard is bare; and the people have to go where?<n><n>### COPYRIGHT BY WISENUT 2021<n>

Choices:  A: shopping cart B: cashier C: shopping mall D: supermarket E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Rationale:<n><br><n>The given phrase refers to a bag that someone would use to fill with many clothes.<n><n><br><n>An appropriate response would be a suitable object that can be used to fill with clothes and other items.<n>For example, Choice A: `shopping cart` is an object used to store items, it would need to be filled with clothes. <n><n><br>Another appropriate response is Choice D: supermarket as it is a place where things can be bought and filled.<n><n><br><br><n><n>Rationale:<n><br><br><br><n>The given sentence can be analyzed as a series of questions. <n><br><br>[RQST QN] Where would you get a bag?<n><br><n>[RQST QS] After someone fills it with clothes, where would you get a bag of clothes?<n><br> <br><n>The questions become clear when understanding that the phrase ‘...a bag after someone fills it.." is <n><br><n>grammatically incorrect. A response needs to be given to the question after 'a bag after someone fills' with the sentence ‘A bag...’.<n><n><br>[RQST AWN] After someone fills 'a bag with clothes', which of these can 'a bag' be filled with?

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a handle if you want to bring it with you? Choices:  A: briefcase B: coffee cup C: carry object D: frying pan E: on a hat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. Answer: The correct answer is 'A': briefcase.<n>2. "Handle" is a verb that refers to the part of a gripping surface on an object, such as a door or window.<n>3. The verb "put" means to move something, typically something that is heavy or difficult to handle.<n>4. "If you want to bring it" indicates that you are referring to something that is being carried in the sentence.<n>5. Choice A: 'briefcase' fits perfectly as it is a container used to carry things such as documents and other essentials.<n>6. Choices B and E: 'coffee' and 'on a hat' are not suitable because they do not fit the description of "briefcase" or imply "to carry" something. Choice B: refers to a simple object and choice E refers to a fashion accessory.<n>7. Choices C and D: 'carry' and 'frying pan' is not appropriate as they do not conform to the characteristics of "briefcase".<n>8. Choice D: a frying pan is used for cooking.<n>9. In conclusion, after carefully comparing all of the options, selecting "A": 'briefcase' as the most appropriate answer because it perfectly describes the verb "put" in the context of this specific question.<n><n>## Reference Solutions<n>```<n>    C: 1 answer<n>    B: 2 answer<n>    A: 3 answer<n>    E: 3 answer<n>```<n><n>## Links<n>- The site: [https://sundogprojects.com]<n>

The given phrase mentions a child having to have a task to do after breakfast before getting on the bus.<n>2. We are given five choices: A: drop out of,<n><n>3. C: D: wash dish E: Read<n><n>4. Choice A is an example of a phrase that is not related to the given phrase.<n><n>5. Choice B has no logical answer as it is unlikely for a child to ask questions while performing other chores.<n><n>6. However, the given phrase specified that this chore would be after "breakfast". Furthermore, it doesn't make sense for this chore to be done after breakfast before getting on a bus.<n><n>In conclusion, after analyzing the given choices and phrases, the most logical and correct choice would be choice D: wash ditch as it is the only one that fits all of the given conditions.

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where can someone view a county highway as a line? Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		A: from the sky<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The question asks "where" one can view an example of a county highway as a "line". <n>2. The sentence is ambiguous because the statement "from the sky" is not a location, but a verb; therefore, the question could easily be interpreted as asking for a noun form of "line" from the given locations. However, according to standard English grammar, the correct response is A: 'from the sky'. <n>3. The choice E:'michigan' is not appropriate because it is neither part of a county, nor is it a highway.<n>4. We eliminate choices B and C:'map' and 'cross counties by car' as they do not accurately describe the phrase "county highway as a line", as the highway serves the county as an overarching unit, and as it is not a line when viewed from a car.<n>5. We eliminate choice D: 'country', because it does not align with the requirements of the question.<n>6. We only narrow down the choice to A, 'from the sky' because it fits the best as it is an object that can "view" the county highway, and since the phrase being given is "a county highway as a line", we must determine a location that meets those requirements.<n>7. A location is not needed for the response, because there is no requirement of specifying the location of the county or the highway in the question, except the requirement to provide the place where an observer can see that phrase.<n><n>### Reference:<n>- https://www.engvid.com/multiple-choice-question-english/<n>

The program should print the value of the 10th problem.<n>### Demontration<n>You can find the program for Problem 7 from your textbook.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input will look like the formals in the problem.<n>```<n>x = 5<n>y = 8<n>```<n>### Output<n>Output should be x + y.<n>### Rationales<n>You should understand x and y in the 10 problems.<n><n>### 0. What's the point of recursion?<n>Recursion is not a language feature or keyword in Python.<n><n>### ** 1. What's the difference between this program and the program above?<n>The only difference is where we define a function.<n><n>### What do you have to do?<n>You have to make a driver program and five or more problem specifications.<n><n>For example<n>```<n>print(x + y)<n>```<n>or<n>```<n>print(factorial(6)<n>```<n>will be the answer.  <n>This is the program for the second problem.  <n>The driver program should have an entry to run the 10 problems, with an exit.<n><n>### Do you have a question?<n>### Can we make it clearer?<n>### Any further questions?<n>### Any feedback for the class?<n>### Any other questions?<n>***<n>### ** 2.** The same program as before, but print values instead of printing factorial.<n>The above problem asks us to print the values of function arguments through a series of printing statements.<n><n>### Can we change the code?<n>No.  <n>It will not matter whether the values are printed or not.  <n>This is because the result of each factorial will not change whether the values are printed in each iteration or not.<n><n>### Any other question?<n>No.<n><n># **3.** Why the "*" here?  <n>Sometimes when you input the command line, "*" will appear in the end.<n><n>```<n>*<n>```<n><n>### Why

Choices: 1) work as an apprentice for a mechanic. 2) work in the city. 3) do computer programming as a freelancer. 4) make money online. 5) drive a taxi. 6) go to work as a programmer..<n><n>### Your Response:<n><n>## Rationales:<n>What do you want to become when you are 18 years old? This question requires us to choose one of the possibilities.<n>- The answer A: "work as an apprentice" fits the question because you always have to work with your skills. That's why for this reason, it is a logical answer.<n>- The answer "work in the city" doesn't fit the question because it doesn't make any sense to write " work in the city".<n>- The answer "do computer programming as a freemin" doesn't fit because this answer doesn't include you working for money.<n>- The answer D: "make money online" doesn't fit into this question because it doesn'<n>- The answer E: "drive a taxi" doesn't fit.<n>- The logical answer is the B: "work in the city", which is the right answer.<n>Answer: B" work in the city"<n><n>## Inputs:What is a good thing about this song? Choices:  "A" : It gives pleasure to listen to it<n>B: It was very relaxing<n>C: It helped me feel happy

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:What is another term for instituting civil action? Choices:  B: impersonate C: imitate D: instigate E: instill<n><n>Another term for instituting: Choices:  A. conflict C: question D: disturbance E: discontent<n><n>Term for instituting civil proceeding: Choices: A: confusion B: protest C: uprising D: commotion E: riot<n><n>Another term is riot which means a large disturbance, often involving violence, that results in the breakdown of public order.<n>Answer: C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input A: An example of the term is when<n><n>### Response A: An example of: Choices:  R: The Supreme Court Choices:  A Choices:  A Rationales: 1: 1: A:  A An example of the supreme court is  when it allows for the case to be tried in a higher-level court, so it is the opposite of the court dismissing the case.<n>

Choices:  A. A: microscopic B. B: minutest C. C: minute D. D: microsecond E. E: pixel<n><n>### Your answer:<n>The most fitting answer for the instruction "Write a response for each question" is choice B: B: minutest. If a screen is "very tiny" it would be hard to tell what is on it unless it is magnified and made larger.<n><n>### Your reasoning:<n>The answer is B: "minutest" because it is the most relevant answer. 	It is the most relevant answer because if something is "minutest", it is tiny and small. 	<n>This is true because in a dictionary, it says that the word "minutest" means "very small". In addition, "minutest" comes from the word "microscopic," which means "incredibly small." 	<n>The word "minutest", in this case, is the best answer because if something is very small, it may be difficult to see or understand.<n><n>### Review<n><n>### Solution:<n>The answer to the question: "Where is a good place buy moistener" is: "The drug store."<n>If the sentence said the moistener was a "great" buy, it would be in the hand lotion.  <n>The answer to, "Where is a good buy buy hand lotion" is then of course, in the hand lotion itself.	<n><n>### Solution 2:<n>The answer to "input: Where is a good buy buy moistener" can be seen in the answer to the following question: "Where was a good place to buy a moistener?" <n>I think the answer for that question is in the purse.<n>I think the answer is in the purse because if the moistener was used in your hand, or bathroom, then you would need something to put the moistener in. <n>This is what I think because moistener may also refer to the substance used to dampen something, such as cotton balls. <n><n>

Choices:  A: laughter B: being happy C: glee D: opera E: injuries<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is D: opera because Danny is singing in front of his peers, not in a private setting.  The options that describe what Danny felt, B: being happy, and C: glee, are not relevant to Danny's performance in front of his peeps at school.<n><n>### Input The most important thing John wanted to ask his son was ________________. Choices: A: when he was going _______________________ B: when he was going to go to ____________. C: did _____________ go back to ____________?. D: had __________ gotten a job E: if ______________ was doing ok in school F: why was ________ not going with him.<n><n>### Response The correct choice is C: did _________ go back to _________ as it the only choice that shows the correct usage of pronouns and adverbs.<n><n>###Input:You can do whatever you want this weekend except do what? Choices: A: drive B: play C: go to football games D: be happy E: watch baseball.<n><n>###Response:The correct choice is C: go to football matches as the choices A: drive, B: play and D: be happy do not suit the instruction.<n><n>###Note: All responses are expected to have the full sentence. Do not neglect the full sentence.<n><n>###Detailed Example 3<n><n>###Instruction:What was the purpose of the article you read?<n><n>###Demonstration:In this question, the aim and purpose of the article is what we are being asked to identify as our correct response.<n><n>###Requirement:<n>1) Students answer what the purpose or the aim of the article was.<n>2) They include the article to show that they have done actual work/homework in order to answer the questions.<n>3) Students should answer the question.<n>4) If given the opportunity, include what kind or method of answering questions you will use.<n>###Input: The article you are reading is all about what? Choices: a) writing b) studying c) learning d) e-mailing others<n><n>###Response 1:Studying is the purpose of the given article, so the corresponding response is "c" as that is the aim of the article or its point.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The machine was very intricate, it was quite an what? Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Changing society using a violent conflict is know as a what? Choices:  A: action B: demonstration C: understanding D: vote E: revolution<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration: In the phrase 'changing society using a violent,' there is a need for an alternative answer. <n>'Revolution' is the noun phrase that is modifying 'a violent,' indicating that a violent means of changing society is also a revolution. <n>We can see this by looking at the part two of the phrase: 'changing society using.' <n>As a result, we see that'revolution' is also a possible answer. <n>Rationales are given below: 1. Demonstration is the only answer that can be used as a reply for the choices provided. The word 'demonstration' is an acceptable answer. <n>The word 'understanding' is not an acceptable answer because it cannot be related to a violent conflict.<n>The word 'action' is not an acceptable term because it doesn't relate to violent conflict.<n>The words 'vote' and'revolution' are the only two options that can be used in order to replace the given phrase.<n>2. Demonstration refers to an act or series of acts intended to influence opinion or policy. <n><n>### Instructions:Choose the answer that best completes a sentence provided.<n><n>### Inputs:  A: the people of the village B: the inhabitants of the village C: the people in the society D: the inhabitants of the society E: the people of the society<n>Rationales:<n><n>1. The verb 'of the village' is used in order to describe the relationship between the people in the village and the village itself. <n>By using 'of the village' it is indicated that the people of the village are contained.<n>2. The answer that best completes the sentence is 'inhabitants of the village. The word 'inhabitant' means a person who lives or is in possession of a place.<n>3. The answer D: inhabitants of the society is incorrect because "society" refers to a large body of people linked by common traditions, interests, etc.<n>4. The answer E: inhabitants of the society in not correct because'society' refers to a large group of people, while the phrase 'inhabitants of' the society implies that the group is contained within the society.<n>5. The answer C: people of the society is not proper because a society is a state or organization of persons of common interests, etc. The

Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the sentence, we are describing the animal by stating "where it's likely to live". For an animal to live, it has to have suitable conditions such as a warm and humid climate, plentiful food and cover. <n><n>-The lion has multiple choices that would be suitable living conditions for other animals such as the veldt (open grassland), savannah (open and treeless plains) and the  africa (savanna or grassland). However, lions live in Africa, they have no choice and are limited to only one choice.<n><n>-The lions natural habitat is Africa and the savannah. While these choices are valid choices, the lions do not have any choices where they are living. The veldt is not a suitable place for the lion as they do not live here, the choices are irrelevant for the lion.<n><n>-In conclusion, from our analysis, we can conclude that A: 'africa' is the most fitting choice because it is the only location that suits a lion's natural habitat.<n>Answer: A: africa(savanna)

D) She made a loud yelling noise. We see that John is in a wheelchairs due to an accident<n>2. We see that he is in a building and we also know his building has a 3rd floor.<n>3. We do not want to say "up" or "in."<n>4. Choice A: "space shuttle" does not match the description of being in a building.<n>5. Choice B: "Detroit" does not match the explanation of "accident."<n>6. Choice C: "Stairs," does not match the description that John is injured.<n>7. Choices D and E can be eliminated immediately because they do not match.<n>8. We still have the choices: A, B, C.<n>9. To find which is the best match, we eliminate the ones that do not match.<n>  a) If the elevator were upstairs, then the choice C: "Stairs" would be the best choice. <n>  b) If John were to take the space ship, then option A: "Space ship"  would be the best match. <n>  c) If John wanted to make a trip to Detroit, then option B: "Detriot" would be the best response.<n>10. The answer is Choice A: 'Space shuttle' as it is the most logical choice that best corresponds to the facts provided.<n><n>### Input:[It is] The computer is (BAD SENTENCE. We are looking for the noun to replace "is"). Choices:  The computer A: is B: are C: am, D:'m E:'s<n>Rationales: All of the words can mean the same thing.<n>1. An adjective describing a noun cannot follow "is".<n>2. The answer choice must be given as a noun.<n><n>### Output: Answer: "The computer is"<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: box B: apparatus C: appliance D: wash dishes E: implement<n>Rationales: 1. The given phrase describes "the machine" as being "very intricate". This indicates that the machine is complicated and detailed. <n>2. We are looking for a word that matches this description in the given choices.<n>3. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5. The choice C: 'appliance' does not suit the description as appliances are usually common household items.<n>6. Choice D: 'wash dishes' is not logical as it doesn't match the description of an intricate machine.<n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. In conclusion, after analyzing all of the choices, choice B: 'apparatus' is the most fitting answer because the word aligns with the description of "the machine" in the sentence.<n>Answer: B: apparatus<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? Choices:  A: school building B: skyscraper C: business D: grocery store. E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. This answer choice is incorrect because a skyscraper is not located in New York. Furthermore, the given choices are in the form of a list whereas the sentence asks us to choose the correct response. Hence, A: school building is incorrect.<n>2. Likewise, the statement asking us to choose a location is not a list of choices. In other words, Choice B: skyscrapser is incorrect.<n>3. In conclusion, we can reject all of these previous choices, and the sentence makes it clear that businesses are common locations in New york. Therefore, the correct answer is D: grocery.<n>Answer: D: grocery<n><n>### Input The new machine was much more expensive than the previous one. <n><n>### Demostration: <n><n>### Response <n>1. The sentence describes a situation in which one is comparing two pieces of equipment, in this case, a new and old machine.<n>2. Thus, the correct answer is choice A: much more expensive.<n>3. Choice B: much more, which is the contraction of than much is not appropriate because it doesn't make grammatical sense.<n>4. Choices C: less expensive and E: much less expensive do not fit as we are looking to understand if the previous machine was more expensive than the new machine instead of comparing the prices.<n>5. In conclusion, after looking at all of the given answers. Choice A: more expensive seems the most logical and accurate answer.<n>Answer: A: Much more expensive<n><n>### Input : Choose the correct preposition<n><n>### Demstration: <n><n>Choices A:  over B: over C: up D: above E: into<n><n>### Response<n><n>1. This sentence uses the word "between" and the prepositions are "between" and/or "within". However, since the word before means "at or to a significant distance from" and is used here, the sentence is in fact using the phrase "at a distance of". Thus, we can eliminate A and B.<n>2. Choice E: "with" can also be used to replace "of"<n>3. In conclusion we can reject choices A, B, C, and E. Therefore, the correct preposition is choice D : on top of.<n>Answer: D : on top of<n><n>###

Choice C: 'no spouse', means that one of the individuals in the marriage will lose their spouse, and thus lose the companionship and support they provided.<n><n>5. Choice D: "lose money", does not make sense, as it doesn't explain anything in terms of a negative effect to someone else.<n><n>6. Choice E: "children suffer", does not make sense as children are not directly involved in a divorce, although it may be a difficult and painful experience for them.<n><n>7. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n>Output: The shadow will usually appear on the ground, however the shadow may appear on other objects like a building, tree, etc depending on the objects proximity to a light.<n><n>### What is the difference between "a" and "an"?<n><n>- a is used with a consonant sound<n>- an is used with a vowel sound<n><n>### Difference Between Subjects And Predicates<n><n>Subject and predicate refer to the most important parts of a sentence: the subject is what the sentence is 'about', and the predicate tells us something about the subject.<n><n>### Objective Pronouns<n><n>- An objective pronoun is a pronoun that expresses or refers to something that is acted on. <n><n>### Reflexive Verbs<n><n>An object that directly receives the action of a verb is called an _object completr. An example of a reflexive verb is:<n><n>- He saw himself in the mirror. (He saw his reflection in the mirror) <n><n>### Pronoun Case<n><n>The nominative case is the most common case, in which the pronoun takes its subject position in the sentence. (An example of a pronoun in the nominative case would be: It.) The accusative case has the pronoun in the object position; for example: It (accusative case) is coming (nominative case). The dative case places the pronoun in the direct object position; I (nominative case) was helped (dative case) by her. The objective case is the last; it places the pronoun in a position as a complement or as a prepositional object.<n><n>### Interrogative Pronouns<n>

A cupboard that is used to store foods has a lot of storage space.<n><n>In conclusion, cupboard is the most suitable answer because the sink above the sink is a potential place to store cans. Choice E: 'implement' does not fit because an implement usually refers to a tool or utensil serving a specific purpose.<n>8. Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B: europe<n><n>### Rationales: 1.) The given phrase states that the motorway "is known as". This indicates that it is well-known and recognized.<n>2. We are specifically looking for "where", which is the location of the road.<n>3. Choice A:'scotland' is incorrect as Scotland is a country, not a road, and also has no motorways.<n>4. Choices B and C: 'europe' and 'race track' are not correct locations for a motorway.<n>5. Choice D: "new jersey" is not a suitable choice because it is a U.S. state, not an international geographic location.<n>6. We are left with only three remaining choices: E: 'england', A: 'europe' or B:'motorway'.<n>7. When we analyze all of the choices, we conclude the correct answer to be A: 'europe', which is a well-known location and where many motorways are found.<n><n>## Additional Information<n><n>- The following tags are used to identify a task request: Where, What, Who and How<n>- Please note that the instructions do not have to be written in chronological order.<n>- If there is one sentence to follow in the response it must be included in the second blank (with the instruction below).<n>- If there are two sentences to follow in the response, please include it in the second and fourth blank (after the instruction).<n>- All sentences must be numbered<n>- Please insert a title and a signature at the bottom after the final sentence.<n>

Choices D: "answering questions" and E: "giving homework" do not relate to the tasks of "getting classrooms ready".<n>5. Teaching is the task the teachers would need to complete as it is stated that they need to get their "classrooms ready".<n>Answer: B: teaching children<n><n>### Input : The class has started its unit on the human body. A washing mashine does wash clothes but it is not a source to buy clothes. A shopping mall sells many types of clothes and shoes, but does not offer specialized services for clothing. Texas can be substituted with any other southern state.<n>3rd word: texas is a synonym for South which is a region of the United stats in the southern part of the country including Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas, and Mississippi.<n><n>### Input : The sun came out and the temperature rose. Is it sunny or sunny outside? Choices:  a: sunny outside or sunny, b: yes or yes, c: no or no.<n><n>### Response : The correct answer to the following multiple choice question in the sentence:The sun came out, and the temperature rose. 1st word: came out and the temperature or (in English "rose")<n>2nd word: refers to the sun, the word "the" makes it plural<n>The sun came out (the weather cleared up ) and the temperature rose.<n>Sunny is a synonym for sun<n>This word refers to the weather and is not the weather itself as "rose" refers to the sun.<n><n>### rationales<n>1. the sentence contains two phrases that need to be put together for the question to have sense.<n>2. since the question refers to the sun, then it has to refer to the weather, and not the sun.<n>3. when referring to the sun, the answer should be yes, it's sunny outside, but in this question, referring to the sun, it should be sunny.<n><n>### <n>

The choice A: 'box' is not equivalent to the description. A box is usually simple, not intricate or complex.<n>4. Choice B: 'apparatus', refers to a complex or technical device or piece of equipment.<n>5.
